column2: caption="Lord of the Eagles" by [[:Category:Images by Tuuliky
position=Herald of Manwë, Chief of the [[Maiar]]

column3: [eˈonwe]}}) was the banner-bearer and herald of [[Manwë]], and Chief of the [[Maiar]] along with [[Ilmarë]]. Eönwë was the best with weapons in all [[Arda]], though not necessarily the most powerful.<ref>{{S

column1: When [[Eärendil]] reached the shores of [[Aman]], it was Eönwë who first greeted him and summoned him to come before the Powers of [[Arda]].  When [[Manwë]] decided to heed the appeal, Eönwë was sent to Middle-earth to fight the [[War of Wrath]], leading the [[Vanyar]].<ref name="Earendil">{{S

When [[Morgoth]] was defeated Eönwë played a key role in the aftermath. He took the two remaining [[Silmarils]] and held them for safekeeping, but when the two remaining [[Sons of Fëanor]] stole them and fled, Eönwë did not allow them to be slain.<ref name="Earendil"/> [[Sauron]] paid obeisance to Eönwë and abjured all of his evil deeds.  But because Eönwë had not the power to pardon Sauron, he commanded him to return to [[Aman]] to receive Manwë's judgement.  Unwilling to receive humiliation and sentencing, when Eönwë left Sauron hid in [[Middle-earth]] and fell back into evil.<ref>{{S
At the dawn of the [[Second Age]], Eönwë came among the three faithful houses of [[Edain]] and taught them many things, blessing them with wisdom and power and longer [[mortality
column2: life-spans]]. These became the [[High Men]] of [[Númenor]].<ref>{{S

column1: The name Eönwë is [[Quenya]] in form<ref>{{HM
column6: authorname=[[Helge Fauskanger]]}}</ref> however the ancient [[Loremasters]] knew no [[Elvish]] etymology of the name, suggesting that it is probably of [[Valarin]] origin.<ref>{{WJ
column7: Author}}; note that the original text discusses the character's earlier name, "Fionwe", which [[Christopher Tolkien]] considers a mistake.</ref><ref>{{webcite

column1: In earlier works, such as ''[[The Book of Lost Tales (disambiguation)
column2: The Book of Lost Tales]]'', his name is '''Fiönwë''' which translates to "Son", from [[Qenya]] ''[[fion]]''.<ref name=LT>{{LT1
column3: Appendix}}</ref> This possibly alludes to his previous conception as the son of Manwë.

column1: His other early name, '''Urion''', means "He of the [[Sun]]", from ''[[ur]]'' ("the Sun"), ''uru'' ("fire") or ''urin'' ("blazing"),<ref name=LT/> and the masculine suffix ''[[-ion]]''.<ref>{{PE

In earlier conceptions of the legendarium, Eönwë was envisioned as the son of Manwë, but as the concept of the [[Valarindi]] (Children of the Valar) was abandoned, he was turned into Manwë's herald instead. <ref>{{LT1
column2: II}}, p.58</ref> In some versions Eönwë is the one who will kill Morgoth for his love for [[Arien]] (previously named Urwendi), instead of Turin.<ref>{{LT1

column1: [[Category:Characters in The Book of Lost Tales]]
